Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 2014 IEEE International Conference on Big Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
"Big Data" has emerged as a new approach to computing that is transforming science, engineering, medicine, health care, finance, business, and ultimately society itself. The IEEE International Conference on Big Data 2014 (IEEE BigData 2014) provides a leadin forum for disseminating the latest research in big data research, development, and applications. The conference will take place in the Washington, D.C. area from October 27-30, 2014 in Washington, D.C. The PC co-chairs are Jimmy Lin (University of Maryland) and Jian Pei (Simon Fraser University). This award will help support travel of Ph.D. students at U.S. universities who are primary authors on full papers that have been accepted to the technical program or are participating in the doctoral student symposium.

This conference solicits high-quality original research papers in any aspect of big data, including infrastructure, management, search and mining, security and privacy, and applications. Contributions will advance the state of the art in techniques, algorithms, and systems.

For further information see the conference homepage: http://cci.drexel.edu/bigdata/bigdata2014/

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided travel support for the 2014 IEEE International Conference on Big Data. The conference was held in the Washington, D.C. area from October 27-30, 2014. The PC co-chairs were Jimmy Lin (University of Maryland) and Jian Pei (Simon Fraser University). The conference homepage is located at: http://cci.drexel.edu/bigdata/bigdata2014/

Two categories of travel support were provided: Ph.D. students at U.S. universities participating in the doctoral student symposium, and students at U.S. universities who were authors on papers accepted to the technical program.

In the first category, four students were funded to attend the doctoral student symposium. Two of the students were female.

In the second category, 23 student travel awards were given. Of these award recipients, six were female, one was Hispanic, and one was African American. Two undergraduate and two masters students received awards; the rest were Ph.D. students.

The growing ubiquity of big data means that emerging big data research will shape the conduct of commerce, science, and society in general. This NSF grant provided crucial funding to support the participation of students who will become future leaders of the field. Furthermore, we were able to provide support for women and other underrepresented minorities, which broadened participation and enhanced the overall impact of this international conference.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/30/2015
Modified by: Jimmy J Lin
